words: Suzi hi rofʔa ve-hi mora.
glosses: S. she doctor.F CONN-she teacher.F
translation: Susie is a doctor and she is a teacher.

words: Suzi hi rofʔa hi mora.
translation: Susie is a doctor; she is a teacher.
comment: Not so great (same as in English)

words: Pol cofe b-a-televizia ve-hu megahec et ha-xulc-ot šel-o.
glosses: Pn watch.prs.sg.m in-def-television CONN-he iron.prs.sg.m acc def-shirt-pl poss.3sg.m
translation: Paul is watching TV and he is ironing his shirts.

words: Pol cofe b-a-televizia ve megahec et ha-xulc-ot šel-o.
glosses: Pn watch.prs.sg.m in-def-television CONN iron.prs.sg.m acc def-shirt-pl poss.3sg.m
translation: Paul is watching TV and he is ironing his shirts.

words: Suzi hi rofʔa aval hi ani-a.
glosses: S. she doctor.f CONN she poor-sg.f
translation: Susie is a doctor but she is poor.

words: Jen kanta glida aval hi kanta ot-a bišvil mišehu axer.
glosses: J. buy.pst.3sg.f ice.cream CONN she buy.pst.3sg.f acc-3sg.f for someone else
translation: Jen bought ice cream but she bought it for a stranger.

words: Pol hu lo rofe ela pkid kabala.
glosses: P. he neg doctor CONN clerk.of reception
translation: Paul is not a doctor but he is a receptionist.

words: Jen lo kanta glida ela šokolad.
glosses: J. neg buy.pst.3sg.f ice.cream CONN chocolate
translation: Jen didn’t buy ice cream but she bought chocolate.
comment: with ela conjoining full clauses is not so good in this context

words: Ha-tšuva hi o alef o bet
glosses: def-answer she CONN A CONN B
translation: (Either) the answer to the question is A or the answer to the question is B.
comment: Here, both o’s are required

words: Ha-tšuva hi alef o bet
glosses: def-answer she A CONN B
translation: (Either) the answer to the question is A or the answer to the question is B.
comment: Here, both o’s are required

words: O še-ha-tšuva hi alef o še-hi bet
glosses: CONN comp-def-answer she A CONN comp-she B
translation: (Either) the answer to the question is A or the answer to the question is B.
comment: Here, both o’s are required

words: O še-pol hu rofe o še-jon hu rofe
glosses: CONN comp-Paul he doctor CONN comp-pn he doctor
translation: (Either) Paul is a doctor or John is a doctor.
comment: means that only one of them is a doctor; this is ok; strongly exclusive interpretation

words: Pol hu rofe o jon hu rofe
glosses: P. he doctor CONN J. he doctor
translation: (Either) Paul is a doctor or John is a doctor.
comment: probably wouldn’t choose this one (above) [but volunteered]; grammatical, but a little weird; might be good in certain contexts, but it would have the same meaning as the above sentence; a bit awkward (conjoining two clauses w/o the complementizer), corrected to: O Pol o Jon hu rofe.

words: O pol o jon hu rofe
glosses: CONN P. CONN J. he doctor
translation: (Either) Paul is a doctor or John is a doctor.

words: O še-hišʔarti et ha-telefon šel-i b-a-avoda o še-hu nafal l-i b-a-derex ha-bayt-a.
glosses: CONN comp-leave.pst.1sg acc def-telephone poss-1sg in-def-work CONN comp-he fall.pst.3sg.m dat-1sg in-def-way def-house-allative
translation: I left my phone at work or I dropped it on my way home.

words: O še-jon rofe o še-hu sofer.
glosses: CONN comp-J. doctor CONN comp-he writer
translation: John is a doctor or he is a writer.

words: Jon hu o rofe o sofer.
glosses: J. he CONN doctor CONN writer
translation: John is a doctor or he is a writer.

words: Jon hu rofe o sofer (ulay šney-hem)
glosses: J. he doctor CONN writer (maybe two.of-3pl.m)
translation: John is a doctor or he is a writer (maybe both).

words: Hišʔarta et ha-telefon šel-xa b-a-avoda o še-hišʔarta ot-o b-a-otobus?
glosses: leave-pst.2sg.m acc def-telephone poss-2sg.m in-def-work CONN comp-leave-pst.2sg.m acc-3sg.m in-def-bus
translation: Did you leave your phone at work or did you leave it on the bus?
comment: this is ok

words: Hišʔarta et ha-telefon šel-xa b-a-avoda o hišʔarta ot-o b-a-otobus?
glosses: leave-pst.2sg.m acc def-telephone poss-2sg.m in-def-work CONN leave-pst.2sg.m acc-3sg.m in-def-bus
translation: Did you leave your phone at work or did you leave it on the bus?
comment: this is ok

words: Xanut alef moxeret et ha-mutag ha-ze o xanut bet moxeret et ha-mutag ha-ze?
glosses: shop A sell.prs.sg.f acc def-brand def-this CONN shop B sell.prs.sg.f acc def-brand def-this
translation: Would Shop A sell this brand or would Shop B sell this brand?

words: Pol hu lo rofe ve-lo ax.
glosses: P. he neg doctor CONN-neg nurse
translation: Paul is neither a doctor nor is he a nurse.
comment: could be ok if it means that he’s sth. in between, but not in a conjunctive reading

words: Pol hu lo rofe o ax.
glosses: P. he neg doctor CONN nurse
translation: Paul is neither a doctor nor is he a nurse.

words: Mayk lo kana glida ve-lo natan ot-a le-axot-o.
glosses: M. neg buy.pst.3sg.m ice.cream CONN-neg give.pst.3sg.m acc-3sg.f to-sister-3sg.m
translation: Mike didn’t buy ice cream nor did he give it to his sister.
comment: variant with o not very good in this context

words: Pol yaxol leʔexol o kapkeyk o ugiya.
glosses: P. can.prs.3sg.m eat.inf CONN cupcake CONN cookie
translation: Paul can eat a cupcake or he can eat a cookie.

words: Pol yaxol leʔexol kapkeyk o ugiya.
glosses: P. can.prs.3sg.m eat.inf cupcake CONN cookie
translation: Paul can eat a cupcake or he can eat a cookie.

words: Pol yaxol leʔexol kapkeyk o še-hu yaxol leʔexol ugiya.
glosses: P. can.prs.3sg.m eat.inf cupcake CONN comp-he can.prs.3sg.m eat.inf cookie
translation: Paul can eat a cupcake or he can eat a cookie.
comment: the complementiser is needed in the second example; this is ok

words: Suzi hi rofʔa, hi ani-a.
glosses: S. she doctor.f she poor-sg.f
comment: sounds a bit weird

words: Jen kanta glida, hi kanta ot-a bišvil mišehu axer.
glosses: J. buy.pst.3sg.f ice.cream she buy.pst.3sg.f acc-3sg.f for someone else
comment: would be ok as a clarification

words: Pol hu lo rofe, hu pkid kabala.
glosses: P. he neg doctor he clerk.of reception
comment: That’s ok, but the pronoun has to be there.

words: Jen lo kanta glida hi kanta šokolad.
glosses: J. neg buy.pst.3sg.f ice.cream buy.pst.3sg.f chocolate
comment: s.a.

words: Suzi hi rofʔa ela hi mora.
glosses: S. she doctor.F CONN she teacher.F

words: Suzi hi rofʔa ela mora.
glosses: S. she doctor.F CONN teacher.F

words: Suzi hi rofʔa ela hi ani-a.
glosses: S. she doctor.f CONN she poor-sg.f

words: Pol hu rofe ela jon hu rofe
glosses: Paul he doctor CONN John he doctor.

words: Jon hu rofe ela hu sofer.
glosses: John he doctor CONN he writer.

words: Jon hu rofe ela sofer.
glosses: John he doctor CONN writer.

words: Jon hu rofe ela hu sofer (ulay šney-hem)
glosses: J. he doctor CONN he writer (maybe two.of-3pl.m)

words: Jon hu rofe ela sofer (ulay šney-hem)
glosses: J. he doctor CONN writer (maybe two.of-3pl.m)

words: Pol hu lo rofe ela ax.
glosses: P. he neg doctor he nurse
comment: well-formed but false in the context

words: Pol hu rofe ela ax.
glosses: P. he doctor he nurse
comment: generally bad without negation in the first conjunct

words: še-pol hu rofe še-jon hu rofe
glosses: comp-Paul he doctor comp-john he doctor

words: Pol hu rofe o še-jon hu rofe
comment: single ‘o’ seems unnatural in this example, not quite clear why, might be because of the copular/pronoun

words: O še-pol hu rofe o še-jon hu rofe (ulay šney-hem)
comment: this sounds a bit like you’re changing your mind (afterthought)

words: Pol hu rofe o jon hu rofe (ulay šney-hem)
comment: the following sounds better, but not sure:

words: O Pol o Jon hu rofe (ulay šney-hem)
comment: The following was volunteered as the best version for this example (better with ‘o … o’ than only one ‘o’):

words: Pol o jon yavou
glosses: P. conn J. fut.come
comment: The following can be inclusive (difference might be about the tense/predicate type); with ‘o … o’ it would more likely be interpreted exclusively; (but the difference between single ‘o’ and ‘o … o’ might also be related to number marking)

words: še-hišʔarti et ha-telefon šel-i b-a-avoda še-hu nafal l-i b-a-derex ha-bayt-a.
glosses: comp-leave.pst.1sg acc def-telephone poss-1sg in-def-work comp-he fall.pst.3sg.m dat-1sg in-def-way def-house-allative

words: še-jon rofe, še-hu sofer.
glosses: comp-J. doctor comp-he writer

words: Jon hu rofe hu sofer.
glosses: J.he doctor he writer

words: O še-hišʔarta et ha-telefon šelxa baavoda o še-hišʔarta oto baotobus?
comment: this is not good in a question

words: O hišʔarta et ha-telefon šelxa baavoda o še-hišʔarta oto baotobus?
comment: this is not good in a question

words: O še-hišʔarta et ha-telefon šelxa baavoda o hišʔarta oto baotobus?
comment: this is not good in a question

words: O hišʔarta et ha-telefon šelxa baavoda o hišʔarta oto baotobus?
comment: this is not good in a question

words: Pol hu lo rofe, hu lo ax.
glosses: P. he neg doctor, he neg nurse

words: O še-Pol yaxol leʔexol kapkeyk o še-hu yaxol leʔexol ugiya.
comment: this doesn’t have the FC reading; means you’re not sure which one he is allowed to eat
